content.description: Getting off the ground is cruxy, just remember your feet. this climb should stay far enough right to not be able to reach the easy crack but hey
content.location: right next to the huge rock that makes a ramp into the water. the crack on the left is a v easy. this starts 6 feet right of the crack

content.description: Climb the hand crack as it widens slightly and slopes over to the top.
content.location: On the boulder closest to the river, opposite the "Black Ice" boulder, climb the hand crack on the face closest to the river.

content.description: Start sitting or lying under the scoop with hands on the sloping rail of the first rock. with a couple options for feet including left or right heel hooks, establish and pull up through good horizontal hand jams and latch onto the somewhat Dino head shaped boulder, a heel-toe cam and/or knee-bar might be useful. Do a bit of a wrestling match going straight up through the sweeping scoop feature with a mixture of hold types and somewhat puzzling movement to get stepped up. Their is a not so awesome crimp for the pull through the topout. Beached whale it was for me! This was a fun piece of rock and a bit different of style.
content.protection: 2 pads would be ideal. The main landing zone is flat, but to the right are a few exposed rocks that I couldn't move.
content.location: If looking at Happy Puppy. Littlefoot is on the boulder to the right about 20 feet away with the tree growing up next to it. The climb is to the right of the tree. It is actually a boulder set onto another flatter boulder that has been undercut forming a small body sized scoop. When lying below it roughly resembles a brontosaur head. good spot for a nap too.

content.description: Begin at the lowest slopers (yes, the big greasy one is the left-hand start hold - sorry) and slap/hook your way up the protruding, overhanging block. Best to try early in the day, before the sun gets on it. This is one of the few problems of its style in the Flag/Sedona area.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot, the landing is a less-than-ideal rock slab with a dropoff to the right.
content.location: This is the refrigerator block clearly visible as you approach the second set of boulders.
Located on the boulder closest to the river. This problem climbs the crack facing "Easy Ice," "Black Ice," etc.

content.description: Climb straight up jugs to a right moving mantle.
content.location: Face directly left of Black Ice.

content.description: Climb the low-angle black slab with a thin seam for the left hand and tiny bubbly features for the right, using very slick feet at the start. Reach the good holds about 2/3 of the way up and top out easily.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spot.
content.location: This is the attractive low-angle slab facing the trail. Stay right of the big holds around the corner.

content.description: Looming behind the other boulders is this tall, beautiful arete. Climb it by the right side. Start on the obvious large jug and pull past a gaston in the face into laybacks on the arete and a committing move to the lip.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot.
content.location: Around the other side of the boulders from the other problems, look for the large arete.

content.description: Climb the rounded corner around the back of the far boulder on mostly good holds, finishing with a surprising mantel.
content.protection: One pad is sufficient, get a spot too.
content.location: The furthest boulder in the cluster, around the back side.

content.description: Climb the far trailside arete of the second boulder with small holds, technical moves and a reach to a hidden bucket. Climbing the right face without using the arete or the big holds at right is a good tweaky eliminate.
content.location: On the furthest boulder in the cluster, climb the arete closest to the trail.

content.description: Keep walking past the first cluster of boulders for a few minutes to find another, smaller cluster of boulders. There are many high quality problems here.
